Legal_Issue: Does the applicant meet the residency requirement for Canadian citizenship under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act?
Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present in Canada for 923 days and absent for 359 days within the four years preceding the application; absences were due to family visits and accompanying her husband.
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed; applicant does not qualify for citizenship
Defendant_Behavior: Failed to meet minimum physical presence requirement
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient physical presence in Canada during required period
Legal_Standard: Physical presence of at least 1,095 days within four years prior to application
Assessment_Factor: Duration of physical presence, purpose of absences
Evidence_Used: Record of entry and exit dates, travel documents, personal testimony
Application_Basis: Residency calculation based on documented days in Canada
Evidence_Assessed: Days of physical presence and absence verified through official records
Relief_Sought: Overturn of Citizenship Judgeâ€™s decision and approval of citizenship application
Governing_Rule: Applicants must be physically present in Canada for at least 1,095 days within four years preceding the application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant fell short by 172 days; no exceptional circumstances established
Harm_Assessment: No harm to public interest; integrity of citizenship process maintained
Cause_Description: Applicant's insufficient physical presence in Canada during the required period
Evidence_Handling: Official records used to calculate residency days
Evidence_Assessment: Travel records and application data reviewed for accuracy
Decision_Rationale: The applicant did not meet the statutory residency requirement and no special circumstances justified an exception
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Commission / Federal Court Appellate Review
